intro: Guarania, commonly known as the "Brazilian nightshade," is a flowering plant native to South America. It belongs to the Solanaceae family, which includes tomatoes, potatoes, and tobacco. The plant features showy, trumpet-shaped flowers that are typically purple or white, and it produces small, toxic berries. Guarania is often found in tropical and subtropical regions, growing in shaded, moist environments. Due to its toxic properties, it is not recommended for cultivation or consumption.
